or took boats and went out to Bermuda. But

3597.text:
if you were in the heart of the Deep South,
in the black belt of Alabama, you didn't have

3602.text:
a heck of a lot of opportunities there.
>> Adam Rothman: You'd be better off running

3606.text:
south to Mobile or trying to get on a boat
out to England than you would trying to go

3613.text:
north.
>> Ed Ayers: That's one of the things about

3615.text:
"12 Years A Slave" so powerful, just how trapped
you were.

3619.text:
Do we think there were white southerners who
were helpful?

3622.text:
>> Eric Foner: There were a few who pop up
in my book. I don't think there were a heck

3629.text:
of a lot. There were some.
>> Edna Greene Medford: Keep in mind, too,

3633.text:
there were some Quakers in the South as well.
So they were more likely to get assistance

3638.text:
from them. But if I could answer --
>> Ed Ayers: Yes, please.

3641.text:
>> Edna Greene Medford: About the slave letters.
First of all, we have to remember that the

3646.text:
majority of enslaved people were illiterate.
They were not allowed to learn to read. Some

3652.text:
did anyway. And some might have been able
to dictate a letter to a sympathetic white

3657.text:
person who then wrote the letter. But I don't
think there would have been many of those

3663.text:
letters anyway. We do know, I think, about
most of them.

3667.text:
I wouldn't be surprised, however, that there
are letters lurking in someone's attic or

3672.text:
whatever. I think that we don't always appreciate
the history that we have right among us. So

3685.text:
we throw things out. Someone, you know, may
have had some kind of treasure-trove and you

3690.text:
just threw it out because we just saw it as
junk. So the next time you're cleaning out

3696.text:
grandmother's attic, you need to pay close
attention to what's there because that is

3701.text:
how people find these things.
>> Ed Ayers: Some Eric Foner of the future

3704.text:
may find it useful. Something that looked
ike a list to a lot of people. Suddenly in

3712.text:
a different context we can understand how
-- yes, sir?

3716.text:
>> A question for Professor Foner which might
be a bit of trivi. I don't know the answer

3723.text:
to this. Richard Riker, the city recorder,
was Riker's Island named after him? He seemed

3729.text:
to be a despicable character.
>> Eric Foner: I don't think so. I think Riker's

3735.text:
Island was named earlier after some Dutch
person. Richard Riker is in my book, who is

3741.text:
a rather notorious judicial official in New
York who collaborated with kidnappers, who

3746.text:
were sent picking blacks off the street and
selling them into slavery or helping to get

3751.text:
fugitive slaves. I don't think Riker's Island
is named after Richard Riker. I hope not.

3755.text:
If it is, we may try to change the name.
>> The other question for the panel as a whole.

3762.text:
My notion of slaves escaping from bondage
was always sort of influenced by this idea

3772.text:
of following the North Star. But I don't see
any real reference to following the North

3779.text:
Star here. Where did that idea arise about
following the North Star? I don't know which

3788.text:
side of the tree is trying to see if there's
moss on that side of the tree as you're escaping,

3794.text:
what have you.
>> Ed Ayers: Tree on the North, moss on the

3798.text:
North side. I know that part.
>> Eric Foner: Nobody mentioned that to Sydney

3805.text:
Howard Gay when he interviewed. Nobody said
anything about the North Star.

3808.text:
>> Ed Ayers: The Frederick Douglass newspapers
called the North Star.

3811.text:
>> Eric Foner: Yes. And people presumably
knew the North Star was toward the North.

3816.text:
It doesn't -- there were fugitives in this
who went the wrong way for a good while until

3823.text:
somebody said: Hey, you're going south; I
think you better turn around and go the opposite

3827.text:
direction.
So it's talked about in his memoir. He said

3833.text:
nobody knew -- you think it's easy to just
escape? Where do you go? You're five miles

3839.text:
away. You've never been there before. You
don't know where the roads are going.

3842.text:
It was very, as we said, very, very difficult,
very, very dangerous. So people had just a

3850.text:
kind of vague sense and often somebody would
give them a little advice or help, sympathetic

3855.text:
person. But often another person would apprehend
them and get them arrested.

3859.text:
>> Ed Ayers: A lot of times if you were trying
to get to a river, you needed to go south

3863.text:
to get north.
>> Eric Foner: Right.

3865.text:
>> Ed Ayers: Yes, sir?
>> Question for Professor Foner. What was

3869.text:
the reaction of local political entities to
having fugitives, Underground Railroad and

3877.text:
slave catchers in their territory? I'm thinking
particularly of Tammany Hall Democrats.

3882.text:
>> Eric Foner: Political officials?
>> Yeah. What was the reaction?

3888.text:
>> Eric Foner: I think the reaction -- it
really varies from place to place. There were

3895.text:
Northern states that passed laws called the
Personal Liberty laws that tried to obstruct

3900.text:
the rendition of fugitive slaves. The fugitive
slave issue is complicated because as we said

3908.text:
before, many people who are not abolitionists
and not even anti-slavery really when confronted

3913.text:
with this on a human level will have a different
reaction. You know, a person who is fleeing

3919.text:
from slavery. You may be a complete believer
in law and order but you may on a human level

3925.text:
want to help this person. And then the notion
of slave owners coming into the North to grab

3933.text:
people rubbed a lot of people the wrong way
as time went on.

3936.text:
But certainly, I think the Northern Democratic
Party was very tied in to the South as Adam

3942.text:
said. So officials, most Northern officials
like that, would be willing to cooperate in

3948.text:
apprehending fugitive slaves. But then, you
know, there were others in my book, incidences

3953.text:
where a policeman in New York City brought
a fugitive to the office of Sydney Howard

3958.text:
Gay and basically said you better help this
guy because if you don't, he's going to be

3962.text:
arrested in a few hours. Now, he's obviously
not doing what he's supposed to do as a policeman

3967.text:
but on a human level he decided to help the
guy.

3970.text:
>> Thank you.
>> Ed Ayers: Yes, sir?

3974.text:
>> Do we know how the slaves learned about
sort of freedom? Not freedom as such but that

3984.text:
there was a free part of the United States;
that there was Canada? You have the impression

3990.text:
of slaves as being very isolated. They were
prevented from reading and so on. Yet obviously

3996.text:
at least some of them learned about all of
these things. So I'm wondering how this happened.

4000.text:
>> Eric Foner: That's an excellent question.
Adam?

4002.text:
>> Adam Rothman: I think they learned it from
their owners. The owners are running around

4006.text:
railing against the fugitive slave law, complaining
about these abolitionists in the North. I

4013.text:
>> Adam Rothman: I really think that they
to a great extent learned all of this from

4019.text:
either directly from their owners or from
the newspaper that their owners left lying

4026.text:
>> Eric Foner: Also in Maryland, particularly,
half the black population was free by the

4036.text:
1850s. So they learned from free blacks, at
least in the Upper South. There was freedom,

4042.text:
there was the North, there was Canada. This
information flowed around.

4047.text:
Some of them -- a number of people who I cite
knew that Quakers could help them. One guy

4052.text:
got into Pennsylvania, knocked on the door
of a house and said, "Send me to a Quaker."

4056.text:
Can you tell me where a Quaker lives around
here? They somehow heard. Or another said,

4061.text:
"If you meet a white guy who says the and
thou. So that knowledge.

4068.text:
>> Edna Greene Medford: And black sailors
as well coming into these port cities. People

4074.text:
were bringing all kinds of information. So
people are getting their knowledge from them

4079.text:
as well.
>> Ed Ayers: And part of that image that we're

4082.text:
understanding now of African-American life
before the Civil War. There's all of this

4087.text:
circulation of information and knowledge and
solidarity that we just weren't able to see

4093.text:
>> We've mentioned Canada, eh, quite a lot.
>> [Laughter]

4097.text:
>> I was curious. You've already said that
the Canadian government said that they would

4101.text:
not be sent back. Most of the refugees who
ended up in Canada, did most of them stay

4107.text:
there or did they come back? Did they wait
until after the Civil War?

4111.text:
>> Eric Foner: A lot of them came back during
the Civil War. Once it was pretty clear that

4117.text:
they were not capturing fugitive slaves anymore
in the North, a good number came back. Some

4123.text:
enlisted in the Union Army, men. But quite
a few stayed, also. They had made homes, gotten

4129.text:
jobs. And actually they had far more rights
in Canada than they did in the Northern United

4135.text:
States. They could vote there. They could
serve on juries. They had better job opportunities.

4142.text:
So, you know, some came back but a lot didn't
actually.

4148.text:
>> So you all brought up techniques of how
slaves were able to get to freedom. My question

4155.text:
is: What do you think was the best way for
a slave to stay free?

4161.text:
>> Edna Greene Medford: To stay free or to
get free?

4169.text:
>> Edna Greene Medford: Well, depending upon
where you were. If you were near a waterway,

4176.text:
you know, the most reasonable way, perhaps,
would be to stowaway onboard a ship or a boat

4183.text:
or to take a boat, commandeer boat and just
get there. But once you were there, depending

4190.text:
upon where you were -- especially after 1850
if you are in Philadelphia or New York, you're

4198.text:
not safe. So you have to go to Canada. And
even once you're in Canada, you're not safe.

4204.text:
Because there are people who are pursuing
fugitives into Canada as well. You're not

4209.text:
supposed to be, but they are doing that.
There's some people who leave this area, the

4214.text:
area entirely, and they go to Europe; the
lucky ones. So it's a very, very difficult

4221.text:
thing to remain free once you've acquired
that freedom after 1850.

4228.text:
>> Ed Ayers: One of the things Professor Foner
mentions in passing, most of the white people

4232.text:
in the South railing against runaway slaves
thought they were running away to someplace

4239.text:
close to home, in a swamp or the woods, the
mountains, where they would -- that's a tenuous

4245.text:
freedom. But it was a freedom that people
were willing to risk their lives to get. But

4251.text:
basically the answer is get as far away from
slavery as you possibly can. But just because

4256.text:
people couldn't escape to the North to Canada
doesn't mean they didn't try to escape to

4260.text:
whatever kind of freedom they could get.
Yes?

4264.text:
>> When a lot of people think about slavery,
a lot of people think that slaves were a monolithic

4270.text:
group but there were slaves who lived on large
plantations, slaves who lived in small farms,

4276.text:
maybe 10 or less people. There were house
slaves. There were slaves who hired out. So

4282.text:
there was a lot of diversity. There was a
small number who were literate or semi-literate,

4287.text:
some who were biracial. So the question is:
Is there a common demographic profile of a

4295.text:
runaway slave? For example, if we say that
runaways tended not to be slaves who lived

4302.text:
on large plantations or maybe tended to be
biracial or tended to be semi-literate? Is

4309.text:
there any information we have about what the
average or what the most common runaway looked

4316.text:
like or was?
>> Adam Rothman: Great question.

4318.text:
>> Eric Foner: I did this analysis of the
200 or so who were described in this "Record

4325.text:
of Fugitives." And, yes -- first of all, the
large -- 75% of them were men. It was easier.

4334.text:
And most of them were fairly young. The average
age was 25. They were young men in their 20s.

4339.text:
But there were women. There were even young
children, as you said. But it was easier for

4344.text:
a young, strong guy like Frederick Douglass
when he ran away than an older person, obviously,

4350.text:
or an infirm person.
But they represented -- these fugitives represented

4354.text:
every single kind of slave you mentioned.
There were people from plantations, from small

4359.text:
farms, from cities. There were artisans. There
were house servants, field hands. You name

4365.text:
it. Every single kind of slave pops up in
this thing. So the desire for freedom was

4371.text:
not limited to any one particular demographic
group in the slave community. But the physical

4378.text:
ability, so to speak, to do it was presumably,
you know, a certain kind of people have that

4383.text:
more than others.
>> Ed Ayers: And sometimes single men would

4388.text:
send for their families as soon as they got
there.

4390.text:
>> Eric Foner:Right.
>> Ed Ayers: We only have eight more minutes.

4394.text:
See if we can answer as many questions as
we can.

4398.text:
Yes, sir?
>> I've had an historic puzzle piece to share

4401.text:
with Professor Rothman. It went to your comment
about how the study with this book and how

4409.text:
it would be nice to go across and West. This
past summer, 150th Anniversary, Gettysburg,

4416.text:
seminary opened up to the public and they
opened this fabulous museum. They had a panel.

4422.text:
And in it they were talking about Thaddeus
Stevens and how -- he was in the Lincoln Museum,

4428.text:
represented by Tommy Lee Jones for folks if
you want to know who Thaddeus Stevens was.

4434.text:
In the movie he had a common law black wife.
The thing I found amazing, he represented

4441.text:
at the Gettysburg Congressional District.
And he was very active in the Underground

4445.text:
Railroad. And he later became a member of
Congress and later of the House. So here goes

4449.text:
to your point that it would be nice to get
a broader history of the Underground Railroad

4454.text:
beyond just Southeastern Pennsylvania. This
is Central to Western Pennsylvania. A very

4459.text:
noted American and yet he was very active
in the Underground Railroad. I had one of

4464.text:
those a-ha moments like, wow, it all sort
of makes sense and comes together but I had

4469.text:
no idea that he was that active but for this
little panel on a museum. I just wanted to

4474.text:
get your response to that.
>> Adam Rothman: Thank you. That was great.

4479.text:
>> Ed Ayers: That's an area that I've studied.
It's interesting to think about when they're

4485.text:
recruiting 54th Massachusetts. That area right
on the border of Southcentral Pennsylvania

4491.text:
is one of the greatest producers of soldiers
for that. My guess is -- they're 10 miles

4497.text:
from slavery.
>> Eric Foner: That's what I was thinking.

4499.text:
>> Ed Ayers: I'm guessing they're there for
family. So they go to fight. So I think you're

4506.text:
right. That same county would have abolitionists
but they would also have the most active slave

4512.text:
catchers as well. I think there's something
about the proximity to slavery that Eric was

4517.text:
saying before, over time, turns up the intensity
on both sides. So the same mountains that

4523.text:
Thaddeus Stevens has his iron mines and kilns
-- iron works were also places you could escape

4534.text:
if you were enslaved. But also a place where
you could escape, it would be good to have

4540.text:
a white ally and a black ally.
Yes?

4545.text:
>> The previous question was a perfect lead-in
to mine. I wanted to know if you got a flavor

4550.text:
for personality characteristics, certain strengths
of character that were consistent among those

4559.text:
who were attempting to escape or at least
among the 200 that you read about.

4564.text:
>> Eric Foner: You know, personality is not
so easy to judge from the kind of records

4570.text:
that exist here. Some of them were very outspoken,
for example. As you mentioned about -- some

4579.text:
of them were very quiet, very hard to get
information out of. I think it's more a question

4586.text:
of opportunity. People who somehow saw the
opportunity to escape and felt there was a

4593.text:
reasonable chance of success did it. And there
were many, many others, I think, who would

4598.text:
have liked to escape but somehow the opportunity
didn't arise or they were fearful, the policing

4605.text:
system was too strong.
So I'm not sure I want to say the people who

4609.text:
escaped have a particular personality trait
which set them apart from everybody else.

4615.text:
I think they had for one reason or another
-- and every slave who escaped had his own

4620.text:
story. They had greater opportunities than
other people.

4624.text:
>> Ed Ayers: Only an opportunity for one more
question.

4629.text:
Yes, sir?
>> One of you mentioned that in Maryland,

4634.text:
for example, there was maybe 40 or 50% freed
men, I presume amongst other Africans coming

4646.text:
through or in the state. I have a freed man
that was in my family, the 1820s. It's difficult

4658.text:
to find much information about him but I am
told that if you, in fact, were a freed man,

4664.text:
you'd have to have what I refer to the equivalent
of a Green Card or some other identification.

4669.text:
Several of you think that's correct. Could
you elaborate on that a little bit?

4678.text:
>> Edna Greene Medford: Freedom papers.If
you lived in a county, you had to go and register

4684.text:
with that county. You had to indicate where
you lived, what your occupation was. There

4692.text:
was a free black registry in many of these
states where your information was put down.

4696.text:
>> Eric Foner: And you have to carry it with
you.

4698.text:
>> Edna Greene Medford: Yes. And it could
be stolen. And you could be enslaved.

4704.text:
>> Ed Ayers: And you had to pay a fee to have
it renewed every year. The Green Card is a

4711.text:
good example.
>> Adam Rothman: I've actually seen one here

4716.text:
at the National Archives in a pension file,
a widow of an African-American soldier from

4721.text:
the Civil War. Included in that pension file
was his free pass from the State of Louisiana.

4727.text:
>> Ed Ayers: Which seems a convenient way
to point out the riches of the National Archives

4734.text:
and the fact that, kidding aside, it's ripe
for history all the time. The exciting thing

4741.text:
about it is there are still so many discoveries,
so many things we need to know about this

4746.text:
history that this wonderful organization helps
us to discover and it helped us discover by

4753.text:
hosting discussions like this one when you
have exciting new books.

4757.text:
I'd like to thank Edna, Adam, Professor Foner.
I thank you for coming.
